title: Brighton and Hove Secondary School Admissions Proposal Analysis
text:
Current Situation

Present Catchments and Secondary School Locations
At secondary school level, catchment zones are the only thing that really matter if you want to know where your child is most likely go to school.
Brighton and Hove doesn’t publish spatial data of the catchment zones, so I had to do my best to trace the boundaries manually.
Fortunately, the Government publishes good data on all schools in England and Wales here:
https://get-information-schools.service.gov.uk/Downloads

History and Background to Secondary School Admissions in Brighton
Before the last Brighton school admissions reform was announced in 2007, Brighton’s admissions criteria were similar to most English Local Authorities (LAs). Parents expressed their preferences for any state school and schools admitted students until their published capacity was reached. Schools and students were then matched using a priority-matching mechanism which considered only the first choice, then using over-subscription criteria to rank and allocate remaining students where necessary (Allen et al., 2013).
Under the UK national School Admissions Code, 2007, distance between home and school is cited as a ‘clear and objective criterion’ for over-subscription that ensures students do not have overly long journeys to and from the school (School Admissions Code, 2007) – and indeed is used as the primary tie-breaker in many local authorities. Where distance may advantage those living near better schools, a range of other suitable decision criteria are listed – including random (lottery) allocation.
Brighton’s authorities have long cited the issue of fair access to popular secondary schools (Eastwood & Turvey, 2008) and consequently, in 2008, introduced a lottery system, alongside new catchment areas to its secondary school admissions process (distance was retained as a criteria for primary schools).
Places at schools are decided using the following published criteria: https://www.brighton-hove.gov.uk/schools-and-learning/apply-school/how-community-secondary-school-places-will-be-decided-2025-2026
If a school as more applicants than places available, the following rules will be used to decide which pupils get offered a place FIRST.

Looked after children and all previously looked after children
Children who have a medical or social need
Children who have a sibling link and live in the catchment area
Children eligible for Free School Meals and living in the catchment area
Other children eligible for free school meals up to the city average
Children who live in the catchment area
Other children who apply
Tie-break (lottery)

It should also be noted that Church voluntary aided, academy and free schools use their own rules to decide which children get offered a school place first - this has particular relevance in some catchment areas, particularly the Blatchington Mill and Hove Park catchment area where Cardinal Newman (Catholic) and the King’S School (Free) are located.

title: Brighton and Hove Secondary School Admissions Proposal Analysis
section: Objectives of the Proposed Admissions Changes
text:
Objectives of the Proposed Admissions Changes
In the supplied PowerPoint file, the council has stated that the objectives of the proposed changes are to:

Respond to the issue of falling pupil numbers. Ensuring that available places aligns closer with pupil numbers – in turn assisting with budget sustainability.
Maintaining the geographic spread of secondary schools in the city. Losing a school in the West, North, or East of the city would be a strategic mistake (future growth in population).
Aspiration for all secondary schools to be good or outstanding in all Ofsted areas. Currently, BACA and Longhill are rated ‘Requires Improvement’.
The Council has not yet improved educational outcomes of FSM pupils as much as it would have liked.


Issues with the evidence-base for these objectives
While these objectives are on the surface, laudable, in terms of their aspirations towards equality and maintaining provision across the city, the lack of spatial literacy in these proposals and the skating over of the demand dimension (where pupils actually live in the City) is very concerning and needs addressing.
The council has not provided any spatial analysis of where the current and future secondary school pupil populations are located. This is a major oversight, as cutting places from schools in areas of the city where demand is higher relative to the availability of places will lead to, potentially, places being cut from the wrong schools and excessive and necessary travel for students unable to attend their local schools and forced to travel across the city to where places do exist.
My preliminary analysis below suggests that the way Pupil Admission Numbers (PANs) are proposed to be cut from schools across the city, ignores WHERE students are located, potentially storing up problems in the future. The only reasoning I can see for the PAN proposals are to artificially boost student numbers in schools with lower demand - and coincidentally, presently poor Ofsted ratings in order to continue their viability.
Evidence is citied that better social-mix is associated with better educational outcomes, which might be true where that mix occurs organically, but there is no evidence that I could find in the literature that artificially enforcing mix (by bussing students from more affluent parts of the city to schools in less affluent parts or vice versa) will suddenly improve the attainment. I have not had time to carry out a full review of the literature, but where claims of evidence-based proposals are offered, there is a need to also consider the relevance and validity of counter-evidence that may suggest something quite different. In a cursory literature search I carried out, it did not take long to find some research - https://doi.org/10.1177/0038040710383519 - that this kind of social engineering can make educational outcomes even worse for low socio-economic status students.
Since the first draft of this analysis, a number of people have made me aware of other useful evidence on topics such as school segregation, exclusion and attainment. I’m not going to broaden the scope of this piece beyond the picture that relevant data can paint, but my attention has been drawn to a recent report by the Sutton Trust which can be accessed here - https://www.suttontrust.com/our-research/social-selection-on-the-map/.
I will just note that in the conclusions to this excellent report, it is noted that “Segregation is not merely an artefact of residential segregation that can only be fixed by ‘bussing’ disadvantaged pupils long distances.” and “Widening the intakes of the most oversubscribed schools would have a cascading impact on other schools in the area, and create a more balanced system overall”. Given, as we will see below, the proposals presented by the Council include the former and not the latter, it is clear that a wider evidence base may need to be considered.

section: Spatial Distribution of Current Primary School Pupils in Brighton and Hove
text:
Spatial Distribution of Current Primary School Pupils in Brighton and Hove
Brighton and Hove council will have detailed data on where current primary school pupils in the City live. Most of these will be the pupils that attend secondary schools in 2026. This data is not publicly available, as far as I can tell, and I have not had time to fill out access requests to access the Schools Census - https://www.gov.uk/guidance/complete-the-school-census/data-items-2024-to-2025 - which could be used to confirm where students attending primary schools in the city currently live.
However, I have been able to obtain some data on the spatial distribution of young people from the 2021 Census:
https://www.nomisweb.co.uk/sources/census_2021
From here I downloaded at the Lower Layer Super Output Area (LSOA - roughly neighbourhood) level, data for all people and those aged 5-9 and 10-15 in 2021.
Those who were 5 in 2021 will be 8 now and 10 in 2026 when the proposed changes are due to come into effect. Those who were 10 in 2021 will be 13 now and 16 in 2026, so I will focus on the 5-9 year olds.

In the table above there are a few things to note:

My estimates aren’t too far off the published estimates in the consultation PowerPoint. In there, it is claimed that the school role in 2026 will be 2276 pupils. If we sum the estimated 5-year olds across all catchments (excluding BL_HV_CN_KG as this is an aggregation of Blatchington Mill, Hove Park, Cardinal Newman and King’s School for comparison purposes late) we get 2444. The reasons for the slight over-estimate are varied - some of these pupils will go to independent schools or be home schooled, reducing the B&H PAN estimates. Some children will have left the area and not been replaced by new arrivals, reducing the PAN estimates. There are probably other plausible reasons too, but we are close enough (168 off) for my broad observations to be valid.
Dividing the total PAN for each catchment by the estimated number of pupils living in that catchment and likely to want a place in a school in that catchment generates a ‘demand ratio’.

A Demand Ratio over 1 indicates there are likely more pupils than places available in that catchment
A Demand Ratio below 1 indicates there are likely more places available than pupils likely wanting a place in that catchment

As well as current suggested PANs, I include PANs proposed in 2026 under the Option A scenario published.

title: Brighton and Hove Secondary School Admissions Proposal Analysis
section: Observations on Pupil Admission Number Reduction Proposals
text:
Observations on Pupil Admission Number Reduction Proposals
Everything below is indicative - Brighton and Hove Council can do this calculation properly with better data if they choose to and I would encourage them to do so as a priority.

The Hove Park / Blatchington Mill and Varndean / Dorothy Stringer Catchments currently appear to have more projected demand than places available. The Blatchington/Hove ratio should be taken with a bit of a pinch of salt as this catchment also includes the Cardinal Newman Catholic School (which, accepted, takes students from across the city) and the King’s Free School. The final row in the table includes these two schools in the catchment and we can see a noticable improvement to the projected demand ratio. We can probably expect the real demand ratio to be somewhere between the two.
The Longhill, Portslade and Patcham catchments appear to have broadly appropriate demand ratios
The Brighton Aldridge Catchment has significantly more places available than demand would suggest.
PAN reductions for Option A in 2026 appear to be applied without reference to likely demand.
For Stringer/Varndean the reduction in places from 630 to 570 makes the demand ratio EVEN WORSE. Similar for Blatchington/Hove.
Nonsensically, catchments with low demand ratios already, (Patcham, Portslade, Brighton Aldridge) have NO CHANGE to their PANs in 2026.
Given current demand, it would make more sense to, at the very least, keep PANs steady for areas with already high demand and reduce PANs for areas with lower demand.
The current proposals to reduce PANs very much suggest a social engineering motivation (forcing high-demand catchments to reduce intake which would inevitably force students without places to seek education in other catchments, not over subscribed.

Addendum -
Since carrying out the above analysis, my attention has been drawn to the published Year-7 admissions statistics on the Council website - https://www.brighton-hove.gov.uk/allocation-factsheet-year-7-places-september-2024 - these numbers would appear to back-up my observations on demand within the city. There is very little evidence of demand for places at Brighton Aldridge and Longhill High School - the former with no proposed changes to a PAN which is already well above demand. Schools with very high demand (Dorothy Stringer and Varndean in particular) are facing cuts where current demand is so high that future demand is unlikely to dip below the PAN allowed.

title: Brighton and Hove Secondary School Admissions Proposal Analysis
text: The R5R package - https://ipeagit.github.io/r5r/ - can be used to calculate the travel times between all of the Output Areas and Schools in Brighton and Hove by car, foot and bus.

title: Brighton and Hove Secondary School Admissions Proposal Analysis
section: Walking Travel Times to Secondary Schools in Brighton
text:
Walking Travel Times to Secondary Schools in Brighton
The map below shows the walking travel times to the nearest secondary school in Brighton and Hove from each school. The travel times are calculated using the R5R package and are based on people walking along the Open Street Map road network.
Notably, we can see that at present, most children in most catchments can reasonably be expected to walk to their nearest secondary school in under 1hr. The exceptions are those who live in Whitehawk and Bevendean in the East of the City - areas which are persistently ranked as the most deprived in the city.










More analysis and validation of these preliminary results is required and indeed should have been carried out by Brighton and Hove Council already, but there are suggestions in the analysis that accessibility by Bus is not hugely different to walking after taking bus stop waiting times and walk times to stops into consideration.
R5R takes GTFS data available from https://mobilitydatabase.org/ and uses detailed timetable information to generate these estimate, however, more work is needed to be confident of the patterns observed.
However, Zooming in to Longhill High School in Rottingdean can calulating bus accessibility from the School, we can see that after taking wait-times into consideration, it might take at least 30 minutes to access even the A259 in Rottingdean, let alone access the City Centre.
Given that under Option B, there is a high probability that singificant numbers of pupils from Central Brighton would be forced to attend Longhill, this is a significant issue.
When we look at the Car travel times in the map below that, it becomes clear what options most might be forced into taking.

Everything below is indicative - Brighton and Hove Council can do this calculation properly with better data if they choose to and I would encourage them to do so as a priority.

The Hove Park / Blatchington Mill and Varndean / Dorothy Stringer Catchments currently appear to have more projected demand than places available. The Blatchington/Hove ratio should be taken with a bit of a pinch of salt as this catchment also includes the Cardinal Newman Catholic School (which, accepted, takes students from across the city) and the King’s Free School. The final row in the table includes these two schools in the catchment and we can see a noticable improvement to the projected demand ratio. We can probably expect the real demand ratio to be somewhere between the two.
The Longhill, Portslade and Patcham catchments appear to have broadly appropriate demand ratios
The Brighton Aldridge Catchment has significantly more places available than demand would suggest.
PAN reductions for Option A in 2026 appear to be applied without reference to likely demand.
For Stringer/Varndean the reduction in places from 630 to 570 makes the demand ratio EVEN WORSE. Similar for Blatchington/Hove.
Nonsensically, catchments with low demand ratios already, (Patcham, Portslade, Brighton Aldridge) have NO CHANGE to their PANs in 2026.
Given current demand, it would make more sense to, at the very least, keep PANs steady for areas with already high demand and reduce PANs for areas with lower demand.
The current proposals to reduce PANs very much suggest a social engineering motivation (forcing high-demand catchments to reduce intake which would inevitably force students without places to seek education in other catchments, not over subscribed.

Addendum -
Since carrying out the above analysis, my attention has been drawn to the published Year-7 admissions statistics on the Council website - https://www.brighton-hove.gov.uk/allocation-factsheet-year-7-places-september-2024 - these numbers would appear to back-up my observations on demand within the city. There is very little evidence of demand for places at Brighton Aldridge and Longhill High School - the former with no proposed changes to a PAN which is already well above demand. Schools with very high demand (Dorothy Stringer and Varndean in particular) are facing cuts where current demand is so high that future demand is unlikely to dip below the PAN allowed.

title: Brighton and Hove Secondary School Admissions Proposal Analysis
section: Walking Travel Times to Secondary Schools in Brighton
text:
Walking Travel Times to Secondary Schools in Brighton
The map below shows the walking travel times to the nearest secondary school in Brighton and Hove from each school. The travel times are calculated using the R5R package and are based on people walking along the Open Street Map road network.
Notably, we can see that at present, most children in most catchments can reasonably be expected to walk to their nearest secondary school in under 1hr. The exceptions are those who live in Whitehawk and Bevendean in the East of the City - areas which are persistently ranked as the most deprived in the city.










More analysis and validation of these preliminary results is required and indeed should have been carried out by Brighton and Hove Council already, but there are suggestions in the analysis that accessibility by Bus is not hugely different to walking after taking bus stop waiting times and walk times to stops into consideration.
R5R takes GTFS data available from https://mobilitydatabase.org/ and uses detailed timetable information to generate these estimate, however, more work is needed to be confident of the patterns observed.
However, Zooming in to Longhill High School in Rottingdean can calulating bus accessibility from the School, we can see that after taking wait-times into consideration, it might take at least 30 minutes to access even the A259 in Rottingdean, let alone access the City Centre.
Given that under Option B, there is a high probability that singificant numbers of pupils from Central Brighton would be forced to attend Longhill, this is a significant issue.
When we look at the Car travel times in the map below that, it becomes clear what options most might be forced into taking.
